Detailed Description

A vector describes an ordered 3-tuple where x, y and z are real numbers.

Member Function Documentation

REAL Vec::Norm (  )  const [inline]

Returns .

Vec Vec::Normalize (  )  [inline]

Normalizes the vector to a unit vector: A unit vector is often denoted by a lowercase letter with a superscribed caret or "hat", but is frequently represented by the vector symbool also.

Vec Vec::Slice ( int  nBits  )  [inline]

Returns parts of the vector depending on the input bitmask. Bit 1 set return x. Bit 2 set return y. Bit 3 set return z.

Example
Vec v1(1,2,3);
Vec v2= v1.Slice(3);
v2 now contains (1,2,0).
Parameters:
nBits the bitmask to return values.

Returns the cross product of two vectors.

If you have 2 vectors then the cross product will return a vector which is perpendicular (ie at a right angle) to both of them. The cross product between two vectors (Ax,Ay,Az) and (Bx,By,Bz) is:

Vec Lerp ( Vec &  v1,
Vec &  v2,
REAL  scale 
) [related]

Linear Interpolation, the formula is p(u) = x + u * (b-a) 0<=u<=1 where a and b are the two points to interpolate between and u indicates the ratio along the line from a to b of the desired point. Calling parameters correspond to: a=v1, b=v2, u = scale.

Vec &  v2 
) [related]

Determine if two vectors are parallel by seeing if the two calculated unit vectors are identical.

Vec Projection ( Vec &  v1,
Vec &  v2 
) [related]

The vector projection of v2 onto v1 is the vector with this length that begins at the point v1 points in the same direction (or opposite direction if the scalar projection is negative) as v1.

Example
For an arc, the center vector and start vector are assumed to be in the plane defined by the normal vector. If this is not true, then it will be made true by moving the center vector onto the plane, where normal = (0,0,1). 
    center=Projection(start-center, normal)+ center;

bool VGt ( Vec &  v1,
Vec &  v2 
) [related]

return (v1.x>v2.x) || (v1.y>v2.y) || (v1.z>v2.z); }

bool VLt ( Vec &  v1,
Vec &  v2 
) [related]

return (v1.x<v2.x) || (v1.y<v2.y) || (v1.z<v2.z); }

Vec VMax ( Vec &  v1,
Vec &  v2 
) [related]

Returns the maximum of each component of the two vectors. Useful for statistics. return Vec((v1.x>v2.x)? v1.x : v2.x, (v1.y>v2.y)? v1.y : v2.y, (v1.z>v2.z)? v1.z : v2.z); }

Vec VMin ( Vec &  v1,
Vec &  v2 
) [related]

Returns the minimum of each component of the two vectors. Useful for statistics. return return Vec((v1.x<v2.x)? v1.x : v2.x, (v1.y<v2.y)? v1.y : v2.y, (v1.z<v2.z)? v1.z : v2.z);
